full_title_en: Palchak (UC Davis) Rule for Pediatric Head Trauma
medium_description_en: Identifies children at low risk for brain injuries after blunt head trauma.
short_description_en: Clinically significant head injuries in children.

seo.meta_description_en: The Palchak (UC Davis) Rule for Pediatric Head Trauma identifies children at low risk for brain injuries after blunt head trauma.
seo.keywords_en: CHIP rule, CHALICE, CATCH, Palchak, canadian head ct rule, canadian CT head rule, New Orleans criteria, head trauma, head CT, prediction rule, rule, palchak rule, uc davis, rule out, peds, pediatric trauma, peds trauma, PECARN

how_to_use.use_case_en: Do you use the Palchak Rule and want to contribute your expertise? Join our contributor team!

next_steps.advice_en: Do you use the Palchak Rule and want to contribute your expertise? Join our contributor team!

about.formula_en:
If any of the following is present, then the patient is NOT low risk for brain injury:

  1. Abnormal mental status
  2. Clinical signs of skull fracture
  3. History of vomiting
  4. Scalp hematoma (in children ≤2 years of age)
  5. Headache

Original/Primary Reference.text: Palchak MJ, Holmes JF, Vance CW, et al. A decision rule for identifying children at low risk for brain injuries after blunt head trauma. Ann Emerg Med. 2003;42(4):492-506.

Other References.text: Palchak MJ, Holmes JF, Kuppermann N. Clinician judgment versus a decision rule for identifying children at risk of traumatic brain injury on computed tomography after blunt head trauma. Pediatr Emerg Care. 2009;25(2):61-5.

creator_info.about_en: Michael J. Palchak, MD, is an emergency medicine physician at Sutter Davis Hospital in Emeryville, California. He has been in practice for 20 years. Dr. Palchak’s primary research interest is management of pediatric blunt head trauma.

instructions_en: Note: We recommend using <calculator id='589'>PECARN</calculator> over other pediatric head trauma rules, as it is the most widely validated.
